revealed_symptoms.rapid growth: I swear this mole or bump got bigger really fast, like in just a few weeks.
revealed_symptoms.nodule formation: It’s kind of thick or raised, not flat like some of my other moles.
revealed_symptoms.ulceration: It’s like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back.
revealed_symptoms.evolving: This thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.
revealed_symptoms.pruritus: It’s super itchy sometimes, or feels kind of tingly, like a weird sensation under my skin.
revealed_symptoms.erythema: The skin around it looks red or puffy, like it’s irritated or reacting to something.
revealed_symptoms.spontaneous bleeding: Sometimes this spot just starts bleeding out of nowhere, even if I don’t touch it.
revealed_symptoms.color variation: It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in.

hidden_symptoms.asymmetry: One side of this mole looks different from the other, like it's lopsided or uneven.
hidden_symptoms.border irregularity: The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles.
hidden_symptoms.induration: It feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there.
hidden_symptoms.telangiectasia: There are these tiny, spidery red blood vessels around the spot that I didn’t notice before.

patient_history.content: Hi, I'll be your doctor today. What brings you in?

Well, I've got this thing on my skin that's been changing pretty quickly. I swear this mole or bump got bigger really fast, like in just a few weeks. Also, It’s kind of thick or raised, not flat like some of my other moles. It’s like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back. The thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before. It’s super itchy sometimes, or feels kind of tingly, like a weird sensation under my skin. The skin around it looks red or puffy, like it’s irritated or reacting to something, and sometimes this spot just starts bleeding out of nowhere, even if I don’t touch it. It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in.

Thank you for sharing that information. Given the rapid changes you've noticed, does anyone in your immediate family have a history of skin cancer? Also, can you describe how much time you spend exposed to the sun or tanning beds?
No, nobody in my immediate family has had skin cancer that I know of. As for sun exposure, I work outside a good bit, and I don’t use tanning beds.
Thanks. Could you tell me, is the border of this spot on your skin well-defined, or does it seem irregular or blurry? Also, has there been any open sore or an ulceration in the area?
The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles. And yes, it’s like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back.

Thank you. Based on the information you've provided, the appearance of the lesion is concerning and I want to investigate it further. We need to determine a plan for treatment. I recommend scheduling a biopsy of the lesion for further evaluation and to confirm a diagnosis.
Okay, what does a biopsy involve?

A biopsy involves taking a small sample of the skin lesion to examine it under a microscope. This will help us determine the exact type of skin lesion and confirm whether it's cancerous. Based on your symptoms, it's important to consider that this may be melanoma. It's also possible that it could be another type of skin cancer, such as basal cell carcinoma, or squamous cell carcinoma. We will also consider that the results might indicate a non-cancerous lesion like Actinic Keratosis. The biopsy results will guide us in determining the best treatment plan. Are you ready to schedule the procedure?
